item.title: Covid-19: World leaders call for international pandemic treaty
item.description: Boris Johnson and more than 20 other leaders say another health crisis is a matter of "not if, but when".

item.title: Derek Chauvin trial: George Floyd 'slowly fading away' during police arrest
item.description: Witness tells of last moments of George Floyd's life at the trial of the officer accused of killing him.

item.title: Sir Lenny Henry's open letter urges black Britons to take Covid vaccine
item.description: The comic and actor leads stars in an open letter urging black Britons to have the Covid-19 jab.

item.title: Suez Canal reopens after giant stranded ship is freed
item.description: It took almost a week to dislodge a giant container ship blocking one the world's busiest trade routes.

item.title: Covid-19: CDC head warns of 'impending doom' in US
item.description: Cases and deaths are rising as US officials warned the struggle to end the pandemic is not over.

item.title: Long Covid: 'It's like someone has piled sandbags on top of me'
item.description: A year on since 29-year-old Reece caught coronavirus, what he imagined would be a mild infection changed his life beyond recognition.

item.title: Covid: World leaders in pandemic treaty call and 'impending doom' warning in US
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Tuesday morning.

item.title: School abuse: 'Rape culture' allegations are 'shocking', says Williamson
item.description: The education secretary says he will take 'appropriate action' and urges victims to report abuse.

item.title: GHB: Killer drug to be made a Class B substance
item.description: It was used in attacks by the UK's most prolific rapist and the serial killer Stephen Port.

item.title: Hong Kong: China passes 'patriot' electoral reforms
item.description: The changes aim to only have "patriots" in office but critics warn it will stifle dissent.

item.title: Greensill Capital: Labour calls for watchdog to probe firm's role
item.description: The party wants a standards body to look into access granted to the firm under ex-PM David Cameron.

item.title: Nike sues over 'Satan Shoes' with human blood
item.description: Nike sues an art collective over its 'Satan Shoes', produced in collaboration with rapper Lil Nas X.

item.title: Ghislaine Maxwell: Fourth alleged victim added to charges
item.description: The ex-girlfriend of sex offender Jeffrey Epstein is charged with trafficking a fourth underage girl.

item.title: The Papers: England 'on track' to reopen and pandemic treaty plea
item.description: The PM's comments that England remains on course to ease further restrictions on 12 April is among the front-page stories.

item.title: Inauguration poet Amanda Gorman: 'My life changed in six minutes'
item.description: Amanda Gorman became the youngest inaugural poet when she recited The Hill We Climb.

item.title: Keeping score on UK-EU relations since Brexit
item.description: Despite promises to work together, it has been far from plain sailing between the UK and the EU since Brexit.

item.title: Abortion in Italy: 'I found a grave with my name on it'
item.description: Women in Italy who had an abortion or miscarriage discovered the fetus had been given a religious burial, in a grave marked with the mother's name, without their consent.

item.title: Photographing the "endless diversity" of America by streetlight
item.description: Photographer Daniel Freeman travelled across the US to capture striking night-time shots.

item.title: Is this the future for international business deals?
item.description: A new facility has opened in Singapore where business people hold meetings in glass "bubbles".

item.title: 'Finding work feels impossible for my generation'
item.description: Young people could see rising levels of unemployment even as the crisis eases, warns Prince's Trust.

item.title: Covid-19: 'Wedding guest list cut from 180 to 6 - but we're getting married'
item.description: With weddings back on in England, couples prepare to celebrate with their closest loved ones.

item.title: In pictures: Container ship blocking the Suez Canal finally on the move
item.description: A huge container ship stuck for days in Egypt's Suez Canal is at last resuming its travel.

item.title: Covid: Beccles Lido reopening is 'such a treat'
item.description: Lockdown easing means open air pools can reopen as the stay-at-home order ends.

item.title: Covid: Stay-at-home restrictions end in England
item.description: People in England enjoy fresh air as outdoor sport facilities reopen in lockdown easing.

item.title: The crisis at the Tavistock's child gender clinic
item.description: A number of reports have raised concerns about the country's only NHS gender clinic for young people.

item.title: Evidence mounts Covid jab protects those around you
item.description: Out-of-date information may be deterring people from being vaccinated.

item.title: How bees and drones team up to find landmines
item.description: Drones are being used to track bees that have been trained to sense chemicals in landmines.

item.title: 'I catch rats for a living and couldn’t be happier'
item.description: How to work your way to happiness, and break that daily grind.

item.title: Covid: Secret filming exposes contamination risk at test results lab
item.description: A BBC undercover reporter saw practices that could mean people receiving a wrong test result.

item.title: Uganda climate change: The people under threat from a melting glacier
item.description: A glacier in western Uganda is disappearing, endangering the traditions of those who live nearby.

item.title: AstraZeneca vaccine - was it really worth it?
item.description: AstraZeneca has become a political football in a European blame game over its covid vaccine.

item.title: Suez Canal: How did they move the Ever Given?
item.description: The giant cargo ship stuck in the Suez Canal has been successfully moved after nearly a week.

item.title: George Floyd: Americans react to Day One of the Chauvin trial
item.description: A black political hopeful, a Minnesota resident and a retired officer share their thoughts.

item.title: George Floyd: When does Derek Chauvin's trial start?
item.description: A US police officer is accused of killing a black man last year. Here's why the world is watching.

item.title: Aguero to leave Man City at end of season
item.description: Argentine striker Sergio Aguero will leave Manchester City when his contract runs out at the end of the season.

item.title: Time to make a stand against social media racism - Henry
item.description: Former Arsenal and France striker Thierry Henry says that "enough was enough" and he had to make a stand against racism on social media.

item.title: Jofra Archer: England bowler has surgery on right hand after fish tank accident
item.description: England fast bowler Jofra Archer has surgery on his right hand after cutting himself while cleaning a fish tank.

item.title: Shaw 'massively regrets' pulling out of past England camps
item.description: Luke Shaw says he regrets "letting down" England boss Gareth Southgate in the past and wants to "focus on the future" after being recalled.

item.title: Emma Hayes column: 'English clubs are really behind in Europe - but the gap has closed'
item.description: In her latest BBC Sport column, Chelsea manager Emma Hayes discusses what it takes to go far in the Champions League.

item.title: Archive: Sergio Aguero's iconic title-winning goal for Manchester City in 2012
item.description: Sergio Aguero's iconic title-winning goal for Man City in 2012 when he scored in injury time against Queens Park Rangers.

item.title: Can I have a day out at the beach? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about England's roadmap out of lockdown, and other Covid-related issues.

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People aged 50 and over are urged to book their Covid vaccine in the next few days.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: The rules on how many people can meet outdoors are changing, as lockdown is eased.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 30 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid: What is the rule of six and what are the social distancing rules?
item.description: Lockdown rules are being eased further in England and Wales so more people can meet up outside.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will pools, gyms, pubs and hairdressers open?
item.description: Lockdown has been eased further - but what does it mean for hairdressers, pubs and gyms?

item.title: Covid: Can you catch the virus outside?
item.description: The risks of catching Covid indoors are well-known, but what are the chances of being infected outdoors?

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: Anyone in England who travels abroad without good reason will soon face a £5000 fine.

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and when can I hold a reception?
item.description: Wedding ceremonies are still restricted across the UK, but there are plans to ease the rules.

item.title: Covid passports: What are different countries planning?
item.description: How advanced are some countries' plans for vaccine certificates and Covid passports?

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Which countries are on the red list and what are the quarantine rules?
item.description: Many travellers are no longer allowed to enter the UK from countries on the "red list".

item.title: Where is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine made?
item.description: The EU has called on AstraZeneca to "catch up" on its deliveries to the EU.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the R number and how is it calculated?
item.description: The R number is a simple but crucial figure at the heart of lockdown decisions across the UK.

item.title: Covid rules: What is the rule of six in England?
item.description: The rule of six is back for England from Monday but with some changes - we explain what they are.

item.title: Will I need a vaccine passport to go to the pub or travel abroad?
item.description: A government review is considering whether people will need to prove they have been vaccinated.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Covid: What’s the problem with the EU vaccine rollout?
item.description: The coronavirus vaccine is being rolled out across the EU but there have been delays.

item.title: India coronavirus: Why have vaccine exports been suspended?
item.description: India is a big player in vaccine production - but companies are warning of supply problems.

item.title: Covid vaccine: Side effects and why it can’t give you the virus
item.description: It's normal to experience some mild side effects, such as a headache or a raised temperature.

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Unemployment rate: How many people are out of work?
item.description: The unemployment rate is rising as Covid hits different parts of the economy.

item.title: Covid: The inside story of the government's battle against the virus
item.description: Twenty of Downing Street's most senior politicians, officials and former officials take you "into the room" where essential Covid decisions were being made.

item.title: Covid: The countries that nailed it, and what we can learn from them
item.description: A year into the pandemic, we look at countries that have had some success in tackling the virus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Your tributes to those who have died
item.description: A collection of your tributes to some of the thousands of people in the UK who have died with coronavirus.

item.title: Covid: What is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine?
item.description: The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines should save many lives, say experts.

item.title: The vaccine misinformation battle raging in France
item.description: Online conspiracy theories are exacerbating existing vaccine scepticism.
